definition[0]: if one company or country competes with another, it tries to get people to buy its goods or services rather than those available from another company or country
example[0]: Small independent bookstores simply can’t compete with the big national chains.
example[1]: They found themselves competing with foreign companies for a share of the market.
example[2]: The Renault Clio competes against such cars as the Peugeot 206.
example[3]: The stores have to compete for customers in the Christmas season.
example[4]: The company must be able to compete in the international marketplace.
example[5]: Several advertising agencies are competing to get the contract.
definition[1]: to try to gain something and stop someone else from having it or having as much of it
example[6]: She and her sister are always competing for attention.
example[7]: I had to compete against 19 other people for the job.
example[8]: As a stepmother, don’t even try to compete with the children’s mother for their love.
definition[2]: to take part in a competition or sports event
example[9]: How many runners will be competing in the marathon?
example[10]: Professional athletes may now compete at the Olympics.
example[11]: He’ll be competing against the world’s best.
explanation[0]: Compete is a reciprocal verb This type of verb is used when saying that two or more people or groups do something that involves both or all of them
example[12]: We were competing for her attention
example[13]: We were competing with each other for her attention
example[14]: I was competing with them for her attention
definition[3]: when one company or country competes with another, it tries to get people to buy its goods or services rather than those available from another company or country
example[15]: measures to enable Irish industries to compete effectively in Europe
example[16]: It has to keep its own prices down so that it can compete with other major electricity suppliers.
example[17]: If the pound continues at this level our exporters can’t compete for sales across the Atlantic.
